# Welcome

Rockfalls, Landslides, Glacial lake outburst floods, debris flows and many more geomorphic hazards put human lives and settlements in danger. Switzerland is a densely populated country with many mountaineous areas in the Alps. Climate Change heavily influences alpine environments, especcially the cryosphere. Therefore the hole geomorphodynamic of the alps is changing rapidly, which brings new challenges for both adaption and mitigation strategies. 

Speaking about hazards, the hazard itself, like debris flows and landslides must be understood, in terms of their triggering processes and their propagation mechanisms. Building on that the impact of the modelled climate change can be estimated, which will then helps to identify, which strategies can be choosen to cope with those hazards.

# Damage {#damage}


```{r setup, include = FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)

rockfall <- readr::read_csv("RockFallData_SLF.csv")
```

```{r plot, echo=FALSE}
rockfall_yearly <- rockfall %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(count = n(),
            volumeyear = sum(volume, na.rm = TRUE))
  
# 2. Skalierungsfaktor definieren
scale_factor <- 1e-6   # Volumen in Millionen m³

rockfall <- rockfall %>%
  left_join(rockfall_yearly, by = "year")

ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = rockfall_yearly, 
            aes(x = year, y = count), color = "blue") +
  geom_jitter(data = rockfall,
             aes(x = year, 
                 y = 22,               
                 color = permafrost),
             alpha = 0.5,
             size = 3,
             height = 0.9) +
  labs(
    title = "Rockfall frequency, volume and permafrost",
    x = "Year",
    caption = "Ploting: Tobias Tuchel. Data from: Permos 2025"
  ) +
  geom_col(data = rockfall_yearly,
           aes(x = year,
           y = volumeyear*scale_factor),
           fill = "grey",
           width = 0.8,
           alpha = 0.6)+
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Number of rockfalls",
    sec.axis = sec_axis(~./scale_factor,
                        name = "Yearly Rockfall Volume [m³]")
  )+
  theme_light()

```

# Climate Change {#climate-change}
Since the 19th century the climate of the european alps is changing dramatical. Temperature increased around 2 °C celsius and is expected to increase further (Fig. 2). 

![Fig. 2: Change in temperature since 1940. European Alps are outpacing global average by far. Source: Dumont et al. 2025 ](Image 21-11-2025 at 15.14.jpg){fig-cap="Meine Bildunterschrift" width="70%"}

The speed and intensity of climate change outpaces global warming (Dumont et al. 2025). That has multiple effects, especially on the cryosphere and hydrosphere. Frequency, location and magnitude of hazards in the rapid changing alpine environment are extremely sensitive to climate change (Mani 2021).

<!-- JavaScript für Dialog -->
<script>
function openDialog(type){
  const texts = {
    permafrost: {
      title: "Permafrost",
      text: "Rising temperatures causes degradation. Permafrost can be defined as a mutli-year frozen ground, that exists both in bedrock and sediment. Due to cohesive forces of the ice and its surrounding rock, permafrost acts like a clue, that keeps even the steepest slops and many otherwise unconsolidated sediments together. Without permafrost many slopes become unstable. Due to climate change, permafrost might be gone beneath altitudes of 3850m till 2100 under continued emission growths (Dumont et al. 2025)."
    },
    gletscher: {
      title: "Glaciers",
      text: "Glaciers are in danger. Until 2100 under high emission scenarios, even the largest glaciers might almost be gone. On average in the past 50 years alpine glaciers lost 40 % of their area. Like permafrost, glaciers are acting as stabilisier of sediment and slopes (Dumont et al. 2025)."
    },
    muren: {
      title: "Debris flows",
      text: "When the hole streambed gets mobilized a stream of water, air,  and fines rushes downwars and puts lifes, homes and livelihoods in danger (Qie 2023). Typically such events are triggered by high rainfall intensity. Permafrost thaw, decreased sediment cohesion and the increase in high intensity precipitation events contribute to growing frequencies and magnitude of debris flows in the future. Especially regions with current permafrost degradation and unlimited sediment supply will experince a significant increase of debris flows (Moser 2025). In catchments with limited sediment suplly, no signifant change can be determined, althoug rainfall intensities increase (Brunner 2024)."
    }
  };

  document.getElementById('dialog-title').textContent = texts[type].title;
  document.getElementById('dialog-text').textContent = texts[type].text;
  document.getElementById('dialog-container').style.display = 'block';
}
</script>

## Word Count

```{r wordcount, echo=FALSE}
library(stringr)

# alle qmd-Dateien im aktuellen Projekt suchen
files <- list.files(pattern = "\\.qmd$", recursive = TRUE)

# Wörter zählen
counts <- sapply(files, function(f) {
  text <- paste(readLines(f, warn = FALSE), collapse = " ")
  str_count(text, boundary("word"))
})

total_words <- sum(counts)
```


The total number of words on this page is `r print(total_words)`.
